elements.title: Armor-Layered Listing Wizard Disclosure
elements.problem: Presenting all listing fields simultaneously forces the host to confront the full scope of their self-exposure — what Becker identifies as being overwhelmed by the 'totality of experience.' The host needs their character defenses intact to proceed; a flat, all-at-once form strips those defenses away.
elements.solution: Sequence the wizard using progressive disclosure that mirrors Perls' four neurotic layers in reverse — start with safe cliche-level information (title, location, property type), advance to role-playing inputs (amenities, features via 'Load Common'), delay the impasse-layer content (photos, house rules) until momentum is established, and only present the death-layer content (pricing, go-live confirmation) when the host has invested enough character-work to sustain the final exposure.
elements.hierarchy_principle: Safe-to-vulnerable gradient: text-based descriptive fields first, visual exposure (photos) in the middle third, existential commitment (pricing, publish) last. Each step must feel complete in itself so the host can pause without feeling mid-exposure.
elements.disclosure_pattern: One wizard step per screen. No scroll-to-reveal; no accordion patterns within steps. Each step shows only its own fields plus a progress indicator showing completed steps as green checkmarks (character work already invested) and upcoming steps as neutral dots (future vulnerability not yet confronted). The 'Load Common Features' shortcut provides a cliche-layer escape — the host can adopt pre-written descriptions rather than exposing their own words.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 4 input fields per wizard step. Photo upload step shows a 2x3 grid with the first slot pre-labeled 'Main photo' and remaining slots labeled by room type based on property type selected in step 1. House rules step provides toggleable presets (No smoking, Quiet hours, No pets) rather than free-text composition — preset rules are borrowed armor, reducing the cognitive and emotional cost of articulating personal boundaries.
elements.scan_order: Step title (serif, large) -> brief reassurance subtitle ('This helps guests know what to expect') -> input fields -> primary action button ('Save & Continue'). The reassurance subtitle reframes each step as a gift to the guest rather than an act of self-exposure — maintaining the vital lie that this is about them, not about the host's vulnerability.
exclude: No real-time 'X people are searching your area' pressure signals during listing creation — this premature awareness of demand forces the host through the impasse layer before they are ready
No character counts or 'minimum description length' warnings — these signal inadequacy during a vulnerable self-narration moment
No side-by-side comparison with other hosts' listings — this triggers the Jonah Syndrome by showing what 'full humanness' as a host looks like before the host can bear it

evidence.quote: The great boon of repression is that it makes it possible to live decisively in an overwhelmingly miraculous and incomprehensible world.
evidence.insight: Progressive disclosure is repression made architectural — each step hides the full scope of what's ahead, allowing the host to act decisively within the current step.

evidence.quote: Completion percentage is a good host nudge. Hosts need to know what's unfinished before a listing goes live.
evidence.insight: The progress indicator converts overwhelm into a simple fraction — manageable information that supports action rather than paralyzing with scope.

elements.title: Proposal Vetting Information Hierarchy
elements.problem: When a proposal arrives, the host enters what Becker describes as heightened vigilance — performing a life-safety assessment disguised as a business negotiation. Every detail is scanned for threat signals. If critical vetting information is buried below the fold or dispersed across tabs, the host's anxiety escalates because their character defenses cannot process the stranger as manageable.
elements.solution: Structure the proposal view as a single-scroll page with a strict threat-to-trust reading order. Lead with the guest's identity and credibility signals (photo, verified badge, review count, prior stay count), then present the proposal terms (dates, duration, schedule, price), then show the guest's message/intent statement, and finally present the action bar (Accept, Counter, Decline). This order mirrors the host's psychological processing: first 'Who is this person?', then 'What do they want?', then 'Why?', then 'What do I do?'
elements.hierarchy_principle: Identity-first, terms-second, intent-third, action-last. The guest's credibility signals must be the first information the host encounters because trust assessment precedes all other cognitive processing when a stranger is requesting entry to the hero system.
elements.disclosure_pattern: All critical vetting information on a single scrollable view — no tabs, no 'Show more' collapses for identity or review data. The guest's review history is shown as a compact timeline (3 most recent reviews visible, expandable for more). Counter-offer fields are hidden until the host taps 'Counter' — showing negotiation controls prematurely signals that the proposal is inadequate and amplifies doubt.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The guest identity card must convey trustworthiness in 5 data points or fewer: photo, name, verification badge, review score, and stay count. No dense paragraphs of guest bio — the host's vigilant state cannot process narrative text. Proposal terms displayed as a structured key-value grid (Duration: 10 weeks | Start: March 15 | Schedule: Mon-Fri), not as flowing prose.
elements.scan_order: Guest photo + name + badge (top-left anchor) -> review score + stay count (trust quantified) -> proposal terms grid (dates, duration, price) -> guest message (qualitative intent) -> action buttons (Accept / Counter / Decline). Action buttons are sticky at the bottom of the viewport — always available, never requiring a scroll hunt during a high-anxiety decision.
exclude: No auto-generated 'compatibility score' between host and guest — algorithmic judgment of fit undermines the host's own threat-assessment process and can trigger betrayal anxiety if the score seems unreliable
No countdown timer on proposal response — time pressure amplifies the death-anxiety layer by forcing a decision before character defenses have processed the stranger
No guest's other proposals or 'also applied to X listings' data — this signals the guest's appetites are diffuse and uncontrollable, amplifying the threat symbol

evidence.quote: A well-structured proposal — clear dates, schedule, pricing, intent — activates the host to respond. A vague or incomplete one creates friction.
evidence.insight: Structure reduces stranger-terror. Each filled field in the proposal is a piece of character armor the host can borrow — proof the stranger is contained within knowable parameters.

evidence.quote: The fear of death is to be regarded as an analogue of the fear of castration, and the situation to which the ego reacts is the state of being forsaken or deserted by the protecting superego — by the powers of destiny.
evidence.insight: If the platform presents a poorly structured proposal, the host feels forsaken by the platform-as-superego. Information completeness is the platform's primary trust obligation.

elements.title: Urgency-First Dashboard Information Order
elements.problem: The host's self-preservation instinct requires constant monitoring — what Zilboorg describes as 'never relaxing our watchfulness.' A dashboard that leads with static summaries or promotional content fails to provide the control console the host needs. Without immediate visibility of pending actions, diffuse anxiety fills the gap left by absent information.
elements.solution: The dashboard opens with a single-column urgency stack: items requiring host action, sorted by time-sensitivity (overdue first, then today, then upcoming). Each urgency card uses a traffic-light border system (red = overdue, amber = due today, green = upcoming) and a single-line action label ('Review cleaning photos from Alex' / 'Respond to proposal from Jordan'). Below the urgency stack, a secondary zone shows reassurance data: income earned this month, days until next guest arrival, recent positive review snippet.
elements.hierarchy_principle: What needs doing now (urgency) above what is going well (reassurance). The urgency stack is the host's externalized self-preservation instinct; the reassurance zone sustains the vital lie that hosting is working during calm periods. Neither zone should ever be empty — if no urgency items exist, show 'All caught up' with the next scheduled event; if no reassurance data exists, show a motivational prompt.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Urgency cards expand inline to reveal action controls (e.g., tapping 'Review cleaning photos' expands to show the photo grid and Approve/Flag buttons). This keeps the host within the dashboard context rather than navigating to separate pages — preserving the sense of centralized control that constitutes their character defense. Secondary zone content is always visible below the urgency stack, never hidden behind a tab.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 5 urgency cards visible without scrolling. If more than 5 pending actions exist, show a count badge ('2 more actions') below the 5th card. Each urgency card contains exactly: icon + action label + time indicator + guest name. No paragraphs, no explanatory text within the card — brevity is armor against overwhelm.
elements.scan_order: Urgency count badge (top) -> first urgency card (most time-sensitive) -> subsequent cards (descending urgency) -> reassurance zone (income, next arrival, review snippet). The eye moves vertically through threats before settling on rewards — mirroring the psychological sequence of threat-scan, then equanimity-restoration.
exclude: No promotional banners or feature announcements at dashboard top — the host's vigilant state reads non-urgent content as the platform ignoring their needs
No other hosts' activity feeds ('Maria just listed a new property!') — social comparison during active lease amplifies the Jonah Syndrome without providing useful control information
No lifetime earnings total prominently displayed — this can trigger what Becker calls 'Pyrrhic victory' awareness, reminding the host of the cumulative existential cost of their earnings

evidence.quote: Urgency should surface first on the dashboard. Unread proposals, pending actions, incomplete listings — that's what a host needs to see the moment they log in.
evidence.insight: The host's dashboard expectation maps directly to Becker's self-preservation drive: show me threats first, then show me that I'm surviving.

evidence.quote: Such constant expenditure of psychological energy on the business of preserving life would be impossible if the fear of death were not as constant.
evidence.insight: The dashboard must be always available and always current because the host's monitoring drive is constant. Stale data is as threatening as missing data.

elements.title: Value-Before-Ask Evaluation Disclosure
elements.problem: During discovery and evaluation, the host's character armor is fully engaged. Becker describes this as 'the imagined infallibility of the world around him' — the host is testing whether Split Lease can serve as a new hero system before lowering defenses. Any premature information request (sign up to see pricing, enter your address to get an estimate) demands the host lower armor before the platform has provided a replacement defense structure.
elements.solution: Present the platform's value proposition through concrete, public-facing evidence before requesting any personal information. Show real listing examples with anonymized earnings ranges, verified host review counts, guaranteed income explanations, and process timelines — all accessible without authentication. The host must be able to 'shop for a hero system' from behind their existing character armor. Authentication triggers only at high-intent actions (start listing, message support), never at information-browsing actions.
elements.hierarchy_principle: Demonstrate before demanding. Every information screen follows the pattern: what the platform does for hosts (value) -> proof it works (social proof / reviews / numbers) -> invitation to participate (CTA). The host must receive narcissistic supply (validation that their space has value) before they are asked to invest psychic energy.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Landing and evaluation pages use a scrolling narrative: hero section with a single clear value statement -> income estimate tool (no login required, use neighborhood/property type only) -> trust signals (host count, review count, guarantee details) -> process overview (what happens step by step) -> CTA. Information-dense sections use expandable FAQ accordions to prevent overwhelm while keeping answers available for the host's evaluation process.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The hero section contains exactly one sentence and one number (e.g., 'Earn $X,XXX/month from your spare room. Guaranteed.'). The income estimate tool requires at most 2 inputs (neighborhood, room type). Trust signals are presented as 3 large-format numbers (hosts on platform, reviews, average rating). Paragraphs of explanation are relegated to expandable sections.
elements.scan_order: Value headline (serif, large) -> income number (accent color, bold) -> trust metrics row -> process steps (icon + label) -> CTA button. The host's evaluation brain processes numbers and social proof faster than narrative — lead with quantified evidence, follow with qualitative explanation.
exclude: No 'Sign up to learn more' gates — this is asking the host to lower armor before the platform has earned it
No competitor comparison tables — the host is evaluating hero systems, and direct comparison can trigger defensive loyalty to the existing system or overwhelm the evaluation process
No testimonial videos that show hosts expressing vulnerability — during evaluation, the prospective host needs to see confidence and success, not emotional exposure that mirrors their own fears

evidence.quote: Value before the ask — always. Any flow that requires users to give information before seeing results will lose most of them.
evidence.insight: In Beckerian terms: asking for information before demonstrating value is asking someone to lower character armor before providing a replacement defense structure.

evidence.quote: He comes to exist in the imagined infallibility of the world around him. He doesn't have to have fears when his feet are solidly mired and his life mapped out in a ready-made maze.
evidence.insight: The evaluation page must feel like a 'ready-made maze' — a clear, structured, predictable path that the host can walk without exposing themselves. Infallibility is conveyed through completeness of information.

elements.title: Pricing Defaults as Delegated Judgment Architecture
elements.problem: The pricing step requires the host to assign economic value to their sanctuary — an act that is simultaneously a financial calculation and an existential self-assessment. Becker notes that people draw their 'courage to be' from external systems of power. An empty price field offers no external power; the host must generate courage from their own center, which is precisely what character defenses are designed to prevent.
elements.solution: Present the pricing interface as a pre-decided recommendation, not an open question. The default price is shown as a large, confident number with a brief algorithmic explanation ('Based on 12 similar rooms in your area'). The market range appears as a subtle min-max bar below the default — providing context without demanding a decision. The host's primary action is 'Accept' (prominent, green); the secondary action is 'Adjust' (subdued, outline), which reveals a slider constrained to the market range. The guaranteed income projection is shown below the price, directly tying the number to the host's primary anxiety buffer.
elements.hierarchy_principle: Recommendation above exploration. The default number is the dominant visual element — large type, accent color, central position. The market context is subordinate — smaller type, muted color, below the default. The adjustment controls are tertiary — hidden until requested. This hierarchy communicates: the platform has decided for you, you can verify if you want, you can change if you must.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Three-tier disclosure: Tier 1 (always visible) = default price + guaranteed income projection. Tier 2 (subtle, visible) = market range bar with low-medium-high labels. Tier 3 (hidden until 'Adjust' tapped) = price slider + per-night breakdown + fee structure. Fee structure is shown only after the host has seen and accepted the gross figure — revealing the platform's cut during the moment of self-valuation amplifies betrayal anxiety.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The visible pricing interface contains exactly 3 numbers: the recommended price, the guaranteed monthly income, and the market range. No tables, no multi-column comparisons, no seasonal pricing toggles at this step. Advanced pricing options (seasonal rates, long-stay discounts) are deferred to post-listing settings.
elements.scan_order: Recommended price (large, centered) -> 'Based on X similar rooms' trust line -> guaranteed income projection -> market range bar -> Accept button (green, prominent) -> Adjust link (subdued). The eye is drawn to certainty (the number) before context (the range) before action (the button).
exclude: No empty price input field as the default state — an empty field is an existential void the host cannot fill without anxiety
No 'What other hosts charge' detailed listing — this triggers comparison anxiety and the Jonah Syndrome
No fee breakdown visible in the initial pricing view — the platform's commission belongs in Tier 3 disclosure, after the host has committed to a gross number

evidence.quote: We don't want to admit that we do not stand alone, that we always rely on something that transcends us, some system of ideas and powers in which we are embedded and which support us.
evidence.insight: The default price IS the system of ideas and powers. By accepting it, the host embeds in the platform's authority rather than standing alone with their self-valuation.
Show the price the platform recommends (value) before asking the host whether they agree (the ask). The default is the value; the adjustment option is the ask.

elements.title: Post-Lease Legacy Summary Architecture
elements.problem: At lease end, the host faces what Becker calls the decision between sustained aliveness (re-list) and retreat to pre-hosting armor. Without a structured summary that validates the hosting experience, the host has no external narrative to support continued vulnerability. The raw memory of hosting — with its anxieties, stranger-intrusions, and control negotiations — may overwhelm the positive outcomes.
elements.solution: Present a Hosting Legacy page at lease completion that structures the experience into three information tiers: Impact (guests hosted, housing months provided, income earned), Validation (positive review excerpts, guest thank-you messages, rating received), and Continuation (streamlined re-list CTA, pause option, upcoming demand signals for their area). The page reads as a narrative of contribution, not a transaction summary — reframing hosting as an immortality project that extends the host's influence beyond the individual lease.
elements.hierarchy_principle: Impact above validation above continuation. The host first sees what they accomplished (numbers that affirm the hero system worked), then how others responded (social proof that the vulnerability was worth it), then what they can do next (re-list or pause). This sequence rebuilds character armor around the hosting identity before asking for recommitment.
elements.disclosure_pattern: The legacy page is a single-scroll narrative. Impact metrics are presented as large-format hero numbers (full viewport width). Validation content is presented as a curated selection of review snippets in card format. Continuation options are presented at the bottom with re-list as the primary action and pause as the secondary. A 'Download your hosting summary' option allows the host to externalize and preserve the narrative — making the immortality project tangible.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Impact section: exactly 3 metrics (income earned, guests hosted, months of housing provided). Validation section: maximum 3 review excerpts, each capped at 2 sentences. Continuation section: 2 actions only (Re-list, Pause). No analytics dashboards, no graphs, no year-over-year comparisons at this stage — the host needs simple narrative, not data analysis.
elements.scan_order: Income earned (large, celebratory) -> guests hosted count -> months of housing -> review snippet cards -> re-list CTA (prominent) -> pause option (secondary). The host's eye traces a story: what you did -> what others said -> what you can do next.
exclude: No 'Your listing earned X% less than average' comparative metrics — this triggers self-deprecation during a vulnerable post-exposure moment
No immediate re-listing pressure ('List again now to avoid gaps!') — respect the post-lease integration period
No itemized fee deductions on the legacy page — this is a narrative of contribution, not a financial audit

evidence.quote: The irony of man's condition is that the deepest need is to be free of the anxiety of death and annihilation; but it is life itself which awakens it, and so we must shrink from being fully alive.
evidence.insight: The legacy summary provides the narcissistic supply needed to sustain aliveness. By showing the host what their vulnerability accomplished, it makes the cost of continued exposure feel justified.
The continuation section must lead with the options that preserve the host's identity (re-list or pause), never with the option that destroys it (delete).
